description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Enzymes as Drug Targets.

buildup.text: Enzymes speed up chemical reactions in the body. Blocking the right enzyme can slow or stop a disease process.

discovery.text: Enzyme inhibitors are designed to fit the enzyme's active site, preventing its normal substrate from binding.

twist.text: HIV protease inhibitors turned AIDS from a death sentence to a manageable condition by targeting one viral enzyme.

climax.text: Targeting enzymes allows precisionâ€”disrupting disease pathways while leaving healthy processes intact.

punchline.text: Block one enzyme. Change the course of a disease.

quiz.question: How do enzyme inhibitor drugs work?
options: They fit the enzyme's active site, blocking its normal function
They destroy all enzymes in the body permanently
They increase enzyme production to overwhelm the disease
